articles.author: Jennifer Viegas
articles.summary: A new dinosaur called Dragon of Qijiang had a body that was half neck.
articles.title: 50-Foot-Long 'Dragon' Dinosaur Unearthed in China (Discovery)

articles.author: Margaret Harris
articles.summary:
The life of J Robert Oppenheimer makes for stunning drama in this Royal
Shakespeare Company production, writes **Margaret Harris**
articles.title: A man, a plan, a bomb (Physicsworld)

articles.summary:
Research by scientists and conservationists from the Wildlife Conservation
Society, the Zoological Society of London, and other groups published today in
_PLOS ONE_ shows that critically endangered Saharan cheetahs exist... Research
by scientists and conservationists from the Wildlife Conservation Society, the
Zoological Society of London, and other groups published today in _PLOS ONE_
shows that critically endangered Saharan cheetahs exist at incredibly low
densities and require vast areas for their conservation. The research also
offers some of the world's only photographs of this elusive big cat.
articles.title: A rare glimpse at the elusive saharan cheetah (Biologynews)

articles.summary:
Imagine you're on a particularly boring leg of a road trip and you start
counting houses. You pass through long stretches of country without counting
anything. When you do see houses, they're clustered into towns, and may have
spacious yards with tire swings. As you approach a city (finally!), rows of
houses appear at regular intervals instead of clumping. And in the heart of
the city they shrink into little apartments that go by too fast for you to
count. European rabbits, it turns out, bui
articles.title: City Rabbits, like Humans, Live in Smaller Homes (Discover Magazine)

articles.author: Matt Williams
articles.summary:
In the past four decades, NASA and other space agencies from around the world
have accomplished some amazing feats. Together, they have sent manned missions
to the Moon, explored Mars, mapped Venus and Mercury, conducted surveys and
captured breathtaking images of the Outer Solar System. However, looking ahead
to the next generation of exploration and […]
articles.title: Exploring the Universe with Nuclear Power (Universe Today)

articles.summary:
Parkinson's patients derived more benefits from a salt solution they were told
was an expensive drug than from the same solution when it was described as
being cheap medication. Karen Hopkin...


-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
articles.title: High Price Tag On Meds May Boost Healing (Scientific American)

articles.author: By ERICA GOODE
articles.summary:
Scientists found that newborn chicks, like people, seem to map numbers
spatially, associating smaller amounts with the left and larger ones with the
right.
articles.title: Left Means Less, Even for Chickens (New York Times)

articles.summary:
Florida's largest broker of mitigation credits appointed a prominent
environmental professional to the role of vice president. Alexis M. Preisser
brings more than a decade of experience in project management and ecological
conservation to the firm.
articles.title: Mitigation Marketing Announces New Vice President (24-7 Pressrelease)

articles.summary:
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif. (AP) -- A NASA satellite lifted off early
Saturday on a three-year mission to track the amount of water locked in soil,
which may help residents in low-lying regions brace for floods or farmers
prepare for drought conditions....
articles.title: NASA launches Earth-observing satellite (The Arizona Republic)

articles.summary:
NASA launched a new climate monitoring satellite from Vandenberg Air Force
Base in California. The $916 million satellite will measure moisture levels in
the top few inches of Earth's soil to improve forecasting and monitor the
effects of climate events.
articles.title: NASA launches satellite to measure soil moisture (CBS News)

articles.summary:
The discovery shows, for the first time, that Homo sapiens was living in the
Near East at the same time as Neandertals


-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
articles.title: New Skull Could Be from Human Group that Interbred with Neandertals (Scientific American)

articles.summary:
It's not easy to get a glimpse of the critically endangered Saharan cheetah
(Acinonyx jubatus hecki), the rarest of the six cheetah subspecies.


-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
articles.title: Rarely Seen Saharan Cheetah Revealed in Incredible Photos (Scientific American)

articles.summary:
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla (Reuters) - An unmanned Delta 2 rocket lifted off from
California on Saturday carrying a NASA satellite to measure how much water is
in Earth’s soil, information that will help weather forecasting and tracking
of global climate change.
articles.title: Rocket blasts off with NASA satellite to track climate change (reuters)

articles.summary:
There is a cliche you hear all the time when scientists describe their
experiments: "We expect the unexpected," or its jokier cousin, "If we knew
what we were doing it wouldn't be called research." (That second one is often,
but dubiously, attributed to Albert Einstein.) But like many cliches, this one
is built on a foundation of truth--as the comet explorations by the Rosetta
spacecraft and Philae lander keep reminding us. The latest shocks come from
the huge batch of science results rel
articles.title: Rosetta, the Comet, and the Science of Surprise (Discover Magazine)

articles.summary:
Researchers have made a secure, waterproof wireless keyboard that gets charged
by the action of your fingertips as you type. Larry Greenemeier reports.


-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
articles.title: Smart Keyboard Gets A Charge Out of You (Scientific American)

articles.author: Bioethics Pundit
articles.summary:
(The Telegraph) - A surgical robot fitted with multiple arms has carried out
its debut operation in England, in a technology breakthrough which will make
new treatments possible for the first time. The Da Vinci XI, which is hand
operated … Read More
articles.title: Surgical Robot Carries Out First Operation in England (bioethicscom)

articles.summary:
To a human, two billion years is an unfathomable interval. But that, a team of
European, Gabonese, and American scientists now say, is how long ago a
recently discovered hoard of fossils suggests...


-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
articles.title: Two-Billion-Year-Old Fossils Reveal Strange and Puzzling Forms (Scientific American)

articles.author: By JACK HEALY and MICHAEL PAULSON
articles.summary:
As officials in 14 states grapple with a measles outbreak, the parents at the
heart of America’s anti-vaccine movement are being blamed for a public-health
crisis
articles.title: Vaccine Critics Turn Defensive Over Measles (NY Times)

articles.summary:
A new study led by Florida State University professor of oceanography Jeff
Chanton finds that some 6 million to 10 million gallons of oil from the BP oil
spill are buried in the sediment on the Gulf floor, about 62 miles southeast
of the Mississippi Delta.
articles.title: Where did the missing oil go? New FSU study says some is sitting on the Gulf floor (Eurekalert)
